title: Jevko: a minimal general-purpose syntax
description:
Minimal text-based file format, generic syntax, no data types, no semantics, no underlying model of cons cells or anything similar. It‚Äôs as close to pure generic syntax as it gets.

At the lowest level Jevko is a minimal formal specification for flexible trees of text.
description_plain:

title: RUDRA: Finding Memory Safety Bugs in Rust at the Ecosystem Scale

submitter_user.about:
I am a researcher at Microsoft Research Cambridge and a Visiting Researcher at the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory, working on hardware/software co-design for cloud security.  We recently released a [high-performance memory allocator](https://github.com/Microsoft/snmalloc), which was designed to be used with the [Verona language](https://github.com/Microsoft/Verona).  I remain actively involved in the [CHERI](https://chericpu.org) project, where I led the early language / compiler strand of the research.  

I was on the FreeBSD Core Team for two terms, have been an LLVM developer since 2008, am the author of the GNUstep Objective-C runtime (libobjc2 and associated clang support), and am responsible for libcxxrt and the BSD-licensed device tree compiler.

title: The RISC Deprogrammer
Property based testing: how to implement shrinking correctly
description:
Author note: The original title is ‚ÄúProperty based testing: tale of two shrinkers‚Äù, which is retroactively a bit bad title choice on my part; the title I submitted it under sums the content up better I believe.

This is a talk I gave internally at my company (I‚Äôm also planning to give an updated version at Haskell Exchange 2022 in a month or so), about approaches to shrinking in PBT libraries and their issues, and how the Hypothesis approach (‚Äúinternal shrinking‚Äù) solves those issues yet remains mostly unknown. There‚Äôs also a bit of a call to action to PBT library maintainers to adopt this approach at the end :)

I‚Äôm a co-maintainer of elm-test, the Elm PBT library, which has historically used the rose tree approach (second one mentioned in the video) and recently switched to the internal shrinking approach in v2.0.0. We like it so far!
description_plain:
Author note: The original title is "Property based testing: tale of two shrinkers", which is retroactively a bit bad title choice on my part; the title I submitted it under sums the content up better I believe.

This is a talk I gave internally at my company (I'm also planning to give an updated version at [Haskell Exchange 2022](https://events.skillsmatter.com/haskellx2022) in a month or so), about approaches to shrinking in PBT libraries and their issues, and how the [Hypothesis](https://github.com/HypothesisWorks/hypothesis) approach ("internal shrinking") solves those issues yet remains mostly unknown. There's also a bit of a call to action to PBT library maintainers to adopt this approach at the end :)

I'm a co-maintainer of [elm-test](https://github.com/elm-explorations/test), the Elm PBT library, which has historically used the rose tree approach (second one mentioned in the video) and recently switched to the internal shrinking approach in v2.0.0. We like it so far!
